intro: Inga cuspidata, commonly known as the sharp-pointed inga, is a tropical evergreen tree native to Central and South America. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has a dense canopy, making it a valuable component of rainforest ecosystems. Its flowers are small and clustered, often appearing in axillary inflorescences, while its seeds are enclosed in elongated pods. The tree is also noted for its ability to fix nitrogen, contributing to soil fertility in its natural habitat.
